crops.presented_by: James Stewart
crops.description: A fine-flavored South African papaya, pollinized by a plant from the Sandwich Islands.

crops.presented_by: Institute of Paint and Varnish Research, Washington, D. C., through the Bureau of Chemistry and Soils
crops.description: A large tropical tree of the Brazilian forests, with rigid leathery oblong leaves 3 to 5 inches long and shining green above. The greenish, ovoid-cylindrical fruits, about 2 inches long, yield an oil known as Oiticica oil, that is used in the paint and varnish industry.

crops.presented_by: Arthur W. Burrows, American consular agent, Coquimbo
crops.description: A small papaya 3 1/2 by 4 1/2 inches, with very thin flesh which is highly acid and is used only in making preserves and syrups. The fruit is yellow when ripe with a spicy aromatic flavor and fragrance, but is never eaten fresh.

crops.presented_by: J. I. Case Co., through Reginald S. Castleman, American consul. Porto Alegre
crops.description: Santa Maria. A new type of rice developed near Rio Pardo, State of Rio Grande do Sul, which develops abnormally large ears and is a heavy yielder.

crops.presented_by: J. I. Case Co., through Reginald S. Castleman, American consul. Porto Alegre
crops.description: Fronteira. Rust-immune wheat developed in Rio Grande do Sul.

crops.presented_by: J. I. Case Co., through Reginald S. Castleman, American consul. Porto Alegre
crops.description: Frondoso. Rust-immune wheat developed in Rio Grande do Sul.

crops.presented_by: J. I. Case Co., through Reginald S. Castleman, American consul. Porto Alegre
crops.description: Surpreza. Rust-immune wheat developed in Rio Grande do Sul.

crops.presented_by: G. S. Jamieson, Bureau of Chemistry and Soils
crops.description: For previous introduction and description see 106347.

crops.presented_by: Mrs. Thomas Barbour
crops.description: The "sausage tree" of eastern tropical Africa becomes 30 to 50 feet high, with rough ternate leaves made up of seven to nine elliptic-oblong leaflets; the large claret-colored flowers are in long spikes, and the blunt sausagelike fruits are 12 to 18 inches long.

crops.presented_by: F. H. Brunning Pty. Ltd., Melbourne
crops.description: Dwalganup. An extra early strain.

crops.presented_by: F. H. Brunning Pty. Ltd., Melbourne
crops.description: Wenigup. A late clover.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2488. A tropical shrub with thick leathery oval-elliptic dark-green leaves and small white flowers in large terminal cymes. It is native to Brazil. For the introduction of plants see 106371.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2483. A handsome tree with leathery elliptic leaves shining green above and 4 to 6 inches long and large yellow flowers. Native to sandy places in British Guiana. For the introduction of plants see 106372.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2493. A cultivated variety.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2490. Cuttings of a large tropical tree with opposite digitately 3- to 5-foliate leathery leaves, large greenish flowers, and hard-shelled nuts with white edible kernels. Native to northern South America.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2478. Cuttings from a small tree of rather straggly habit with golden-yellow flowers in loose racemes. For previous introduction see 97567.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2491. A cultivated watermelon collected at Bartica, on the Essequiba River.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2449. Bulbs of cultivated plants collected at Mazaruni Station.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
crops.description: No. 2450. Bulbs of cultivated plants.

crops.presented_by: W. A. Archer, Bureau of Plant Industry
